loans.name: Edson

texts.en:
M. Edson is an individual client from Kihihi. He is 42 years old and married, and he has three children ages 14, 10 and 2 years old. 

He has been selling second-hand clothes for men and women for 10 years. He says that he has no plans to change businesses, but he plans to expand the one he has. 

Edson needs a loan of 2,000,000/= (Kenyan shillings) for 1 year. He works near the Kihihi Town Council and he is able to make 450,000/= (Kenyan shillings) in profits each month in addition to the income from his wife’s salary. 

Before he started his business, he got money from the sale of trees and timber. Since he is a patient person and a hard worker, he hopes to start a wholesale clothing business to earn more money. He needs a loan to buy more clothing to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora A. is from the village of Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 58 years old. Leonora is married and has 12 adult children. To make a living, Leonora owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk food in the local community. She also makes and sells snacks like rice cakes. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leonora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like junk food & biscuits. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Leonora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Some people tend to complicate things, but for Merlita D. P., 44, life couldn't be simpler. Being a CCT* community partner of Talon, Amadeo, Cavite, Philippines, Merlita employs simple but effective principles to make her business grow. She is the wife of Orlando, a laborer, and is a mother to two college students.

Merlita owns a sari-sari (variety) store in her neighborhood, where she sells items that are daily needed by people in her community. When a neighbor immediately needs a bottle of vinegar, a sachet of toothpaste, or some biscuits to eat, Merlita is ready to offer her merchandise. She also sells electronic load for mobile phones. Monthly, she earns around Php10,000.

To help her grow her business, Merlita is requesting for a Php20,000 loan. This is one simple way of energizing her business--adding to the array of items she has in her store to attract more customers with more options and to further meet their needs. She believes that with this loan money, she can undoubtedly increase her profits and make her store grow.

One challenge Merlita faces recently is the number of customers who do not pay their debts. She is also challenged by competition in the neighborhood, since many households in the Philippines put up a small sari-sari store to augment the family income. However, Merlita believes that challenges can be met by simply having faith in the Lord and exerting her best effort. She does not give up, because she knows that soon, the days will be brighter for her, both in her personal life and in her business. Just like any other parent, Merlita's simple dream is to see her children finish schooling.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Purchase of grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Many people long for security, but as Douglas MacArthur put it, "There is no security on this earth; there is only opportunity." Annabelle B., 34, acknowledges that and grasps every opportunity that comes her way. Annabelle has been a CCT community partner since 2006. She graduated from college and is married to Danny, a security guard. Together they have three children.  One child is in high school, another is in elementary school, and the youngest is not yet of school age.

Annabelle manages a transportation business, renting out one motorcycle, a tricycle, and a van to local drivers. The drivers use the rented vehicles for public transport, and return them to Annabelle when the day is over. Aside from this, Annabelle also has a buy-and-sell business and a catering business. Through these businesses she earns around Php13,220 per month.

To help her grow her transportation business, Annabelle is requesting a Php45,000 loan. She intends to use the money for repairs and maintenance of her vehicles. She believes that this effort will ensure that her business will continue to run smoothly and earn a profit. 

If there is one area where Annabelle seeks security, it is in the education of her children.  To ensure that there enough money for her children's tuition, Annabelle strives hard to make her businesses grow. As she motivated herself as a student, Annabelle encourages her children to grab the opportunity to learn.  At the end of the day, all she wants to see is her children having a secure future.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To maintain vehicles used in the business

loans.name: Nyabihoko Tutungukye Group

texts.en:
Levi A. is the leader of the Nyabihoko Tutungukye group in Kihihi. He is 30 years old and married, and has three children. Two of his children go to school. He also cares for other dependents. 

Levi has operated a retail shop in the Bugiri Trading Centre in the Nyabihoko Cell for 5 years. He sells general merchandise and is able to make 70,000/= (Kenyan shillings) in profit each week. Levi needs a loan to buy commodities to sell in his shop. Before starting his retail shop, he was selling tea leaves. He used the profits from his tea business as startup capital for this general store. His dream is to expand further to get to a wholesale level.

loans.use: Buy commodities to sell in his shop

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
In 2006, Pacita found an opportunity to obtain secured business capital. She joined ASHI, a first kiva field partner, and she was encouraged by the stories of poor women of ASHI. She wanted to become successful like them and has used the loans she had since then, for her business. 

Because of the opportunity of receiving loan, Pacita was able to start a  plastic wares business.  She was courageous enough to take all the risk of running a business  because her husband was there to support her. She kept a dream in her mind of having all grandchildren finish their schooling and they complete college. She won’t let her grandchildren attain a low level of education like her six children, whom all are under high school graduates and don’t have stable jobs. 

Pacita had never hoped for anything but her family. She hopes her children  will not have to experience a hard life like the one she and her husband have experienced. She dreams of expanded  her business. She sees herself venturing into the wholesale business in the future.  
 
Now she is requesting new loan amounting 24,000 Php. The loan fund will be used to pay for increased inventories of plastic wares to sell. She believes with more stocks will attract more customer in their village. 

Pacita’s one hope and dream is to alleviate her family from poverty. Pacita is very pleased to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for helping fund her business efforst.

loans.use: will be used to buy supplies of plastic wares to sell

loans.name: Emelita's Group

texts.en:
Emelita M. is from the village of Enrile. She is 29 years old. Emelita is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Emelita M..

Emelita is married and has 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Emelita owns & operates a business venture in the transportation sector providing motorcycle transport services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a tricycle transport service. Emelita has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Emelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Emelita from ASKI. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Amalia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting her second loan for 8000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell such as t-shirts and blouses. Amalia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell such as t-shirts & blouses

location.town: Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City, Mis. Or.

loans.name: Amon

texts.en: Amon, a 29-year-old married father of three children, owns a house in Kasese, Uganda.  For 10 years he has been operating a retail shop and cattle-rearing business which he started with capital of 150,000 Uganda shillings.  Amon now has 3,000,000 Uganda shillings plus 30 cows. His hardships are low capital and lack of sufficient grazing land.  He dreams of having a wholesale business, cross-breeding his cattle, and educating his children. Amon is requesting  the loan to buy beer, bread and soap for his shop.

loans.use: To buy beer, bread and soap for his shop

loans.name: Boniface Mwanzia

texts.en: Boniface, age 45, is married to Eunice, and together they have three children. He owns a retail shop that deals in electronics like radios. He was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend who was already a member. Patrick has been running this business for three years and finds it profitable. This is the fourth loan he is getting from KADET and he intends to use it to buy more radios for sale. If the loan improves the business, he hopes to improve the life of his family, own a better shop – one that deals in a variety of electronics, and employ young people who are currently unemployed.

loans.use: To buy radios for sale

loans.name: Jovis

texts.en:
Jovis D. is from the village of Balugo, Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 35 years old. Jovis is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovis owns and operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector running a furniture making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Jovis has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5700 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jovis joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovis has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to expand product offerings.  Jovis is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jovis from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make furniture

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario C. is from the village of Binakalan, Gingoog City. She is 35 years old. Rosario is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Rosario owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and delicacies like banana cues and rice cakes in the local community. She also buys and sells dried fish and home-made sausage or chorizo. Rosario has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rosario joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Rosario has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Rosario is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the second loan taken by Rosario from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Wafaa'

texts.en:
Wafa’a is a struggling woman from Marka- Amman.  She is 36 years old and a mother of five.

Years ago, Wafa’a started her business using her own savings; she opened a small grocery shop where she worked with her husband, who was distributing goods using his bus.

Wafa’a is requesting a loan of 2000 JD to decorate her store and buy additional goods.

loans.use: To decorate her store and buy additional goods

loans.name: Dionicio

texts.en:
Dionicio A. Sr. is from the village of Bugallon, Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 52 years old. Dionicio is married and has three grown children. To make a living, Dionicio raises crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for more than 30 years and earns approximately 50000 PHP every harvesting season (after four months).

In 2009, Dionicio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Dionicio is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops. This will be the third loan taken by Dionicio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Rugando Farmers And Traders Group A

texts.en: M. Zepher is the leader of the Rugando Farmers and Traders Association. He is 38 years old and is married.  He has 6 children, all are over 6 years old and are in school.  He is involved in the farming of bananas, maize, millet and beans. Some of these crops he grows from his home in Nyamirambi, and sells to the local community as well as to the people at the market.  He is able to make 200,000 in monthly profit. Zepher is also involved in goat raising.  He needs a loan to be able to expand and improve his farming activities.  He was inspired 7 years ago by the ready market for the produce and goats that he sells.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for plantations

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios B. is from the village of Cabantian, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old. Remedios is married and has one grown child. To make a living, Remedios runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk foods in the local community. Remedios has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Remedios joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like beverages and junk foods. This will be the sixth loan taken by Remedios from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Vicent

texts.en:
Vicent, aged 29 years, is a married man with two children living in Kyenjojo Uganda. 

He has been a butcher and cattle dealer for the last three years. He started with buying and reselling goats and now trades in cows. 

His goal is to have a refrigerator for storing meat and to educate his children. Vincent needs the loan to buy cattle for resale.

loans.use: To buy cattle for resale

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is 35 years old.  He is from Al Hussein, Amman, and is a father of four.

Hussein started his business by opening a small shop for used clothes to provide his family with a steady income.

Hussein is requesting a loan of 1500 JD to increase capital and purchase additional clothes.

Hussein is looking to open new branches for his shop and increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothes

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Yen E., age 58, lives in the Province of Kompong Cham, which is the best territory for farming. Yen E. is a married woman who is devoted to her four children. All of them are employed in different jobs, and they always share their salary with Yen E. every month. Yen E. and her husband have a few farms that they inherited from their grandparents. This couple now plant peanut and potato on their farmland, and they always get a good result from their crops. In Cambodia, we have two kinds of TV, one is color TV and the other one is black and white TV. People who live in the province use black and white TV, so they use battery to connect with their black and white TV for watching TV and to light their house. In order to earn more income, Yen E.’s husband wants to buy a machine for entering water into battery for his neighbors and other villagers who use black and white TV. That is the reason why Yen E. is requesting a loan from Kiva. Note: Yen E. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a machine for entering water into battery.

loans.name: Rebecca Wavinya

texts.en:
Rebecca is a 35-year-old single lady.  She is a mother of two children, aged 4 and 10. She lives in Wote in the Makueni district.

She sells mobile phones and accessories. This is her primary business, which she has been running for the last six years. 

She came to know about KADET LTD through a friend who was already a member.  She has never borrowed from any other financial institutions.

With this loan, she plans to add more phones and other fast moving products for sale.  

In the future, she hopes to open a cyber cafe/computer college and also to build some rental houses for added income.

loans.use: To buy mobile phones accessories (Kshs 10000), and mobile phones (Kshs 30000)

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 50 years old and single.  She lives with three dependents/siblings in their family house. Her family goal is to construct houses for renting.  Agnes is an employee of British American Tobacco and has been working there for 13 years. She hopes to retire and become self- employed in future. She wants the loan to build a house.

loans.use: To construct a house.

loans.name: Jovie

texts.en:
Jovie E. is from the village of Maquilao, in Tangub City. She is 30 years old. Jovie is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovie owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Jovie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jovie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC. Jovie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jovie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, seedlings & young crops

loans.name: Bienvenido

texts.en:
Bienvenido M. is from the village of Manaoag, Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 28 years old. Bienvenido is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Bienvenido plants and harvests corn for sale. Bienvenido has been engaged in his business for over eight years and earns approximately 60,000 PHP every harvesting season (every four months).

In 2009, Bienvenido joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bienvenido has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Bienvenido is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP for the same purpose. 

This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Bienvenido from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Pauline Wambui

texts.en:
Pauline is 55 years old.  She is married to N. Kabia. They have two children. Pauline has a grocery store, which adds to her husband's income. She has been running this shop for a period of five years, with a profit of about Kshs 4,000 per month.

This is her first loan from KADET LTD.  She wants to use it to buy carrots and tomatoes for sale. She hopes to improve the living standards of her family by expanding her shop to get more income.  She also hopes to give her children a quality education.

loans.use: To buy carrots and tomatoes

loans.name: Rugando Farmers And Tradesr Group B

texts.en: A. Grace is the leader of Rugando Farmers and Traders Association, Group B. She is 34 years old and married with 4 children, all above 6 years. Grace has a bar and grocery store where she sells beer, drinks, and edibles from Nyamirambi.  She sells mostly to the local people and travelers.  She makes 220,000 in monthly profit, in addition to her income from farming. Grace needs a loan to be able to buy more beer, especially for the festive season.

loans.use: To buy more beers for resale

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en:
Ala’a is 32 years old and is a single man from Al Ashrafieh, Amman.

Ala’a has his own barber shop and he is requesting a loan of 1500 JD to do maintenance for his shop and to purchase new equipment.

Ala’a is looking to expand the space of his shop by purchasing or renting a nearby shop.

loans.use: To do maintenance for his shop and to purchase new equipment

loans.name: Silvestre

texts.en:
Silvestre A. is from the village of San Miguel, Gingoog City. He is 31 years old, separated from spouse, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Silvestre owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorela or habal-habal services while his wife is buying and selling foods to local community members. Silvestre has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Silvestre joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Silvestre has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI., which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Silvestre is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be Silvestre's second loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

location.town: San Miguel, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Fathiya

texts.en:
Fathiya I. is a housewife and mother of two daughters from Kufor Raie Village in Jenin district. Kufor Raie is famous for its almonds trees. Fathiya's son bought a car three years ago and was able to pay much of its price from his savings, but he still needs $3,000 to pay the full amount, which Fathiya took from FATEN to help her son own the car.

Fathiya's son will be able to make a better income now as he won't have to share the money he earns with the previous owner of the car.

Fathiya's husband appears in the picture here because she is a conservative woman and doesn't want her picture posted.

loans.use: To pay the last payment of a taxi car

loans.name: Lida

texts.en:
Lida B. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 47 years old. Lida is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Lida owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk foods in the local community. Lida has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Lida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and  living situation. Lida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Lida is requesting a new loan of 16000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like beverages and junk foods. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Lida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kalooli

texts.en: Kalooli K. is an individual client from Mubende. He is 49 years old and married with 4 children.  He has a retail shop in Kyenda that has been in existence for 2 years. Before the shop, he managed his farming business, selling what he grew.  Now, he can buy from other farmers if his stock is not enough for his customers. He is friendly and is very successful with what he does.  He needs a loan to be able to buy more stock for his shop so that he can make more sales.

loans.use: To restock store

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros S. is from the village of Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Milagros is married and has three school-aged children. 

To make a living, Milagros owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk foods in the local community. Milagros has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Milagros joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Milagros has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2009 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like junk foods and beverages. This will be the fourth loan taken by Milagros from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a hardworking married man with five children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He dreams of building a permanent house and educating his children. 

Joseph has had a boutique for the last ten years, and he would like a loan to purchase second-hand clothes for resale. 

In the future, he hopes to change to first-hand clothes.

loans.use: To purchase second-hand clothes for resale

loans.name: Tang

texts.en:
Tang E. earns a living by raising pigs behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. Her husband is a firewood seller in Kompong Tom Province. The couple has eight children, six of whom are single and the other two, married. 

One of her children sells products such as fast food, soft drinks, cooking ingredients, and plastic products. She always shares her profits with Tang E..
 
Tang E.’s child is doing well, and she wishes to invest in her selling business. To do that, Tang E. has requested a loan of $1,200 to help her child to buy essential inventory for selling, and also to buy many sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs.

loans.use: To buy  inventory for her daughter's business and to buy feed for her own pigs

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr: Elle a 45 ans et mère de 2 enfants. Elle est mariée. Elle exerce comme activité la vente de pagne en gros et en détail.  Elle s’approvisionne dans le pays voisin le Ghana à Accra et revient vendre à Lomé. Elle fait dans cette activité 8 ans déjà. Elle est née à Lomé et vit dans le quartier Klouvi-Kondji.  Elle demande un prêt pour acheter de nouveaux de pagnes.
texts.en: This woman is 45 years old and has 2 children. She is married. She runs a business selling pagnes (a type of brightly-printed West African cloth) in bulk and at retail. She obtains her goods in the neighbouring country of Ghana, in Accra, and returns to sell them in Lomé. She has run this business for 8 years already. She was born in Lomé and lives in the Klouvi-Kondji area. She is seeking a loan to buy new pagnes.

loans.use: To buy and sell pagnes (a type of West African cloth)

loans.name: George

texts.en: K. George is an individual client from Rukungiri.  He is 35 years old and married with 2 children. George is an agriculturalist involved in the growing and sale of matooke (bananas of the plantain type) from Kyatoko.  He sells to both the local people and travelers.  He is able to make an average profit of 260,000, in addition to the sale of coffee and a retail shop he has in the same area. George needs a loan to be able to upgrade his 6-year-old banana plantation to give him more revenue. He is a very hardworking gentleman and plans to build a permanent house for his family.

loans.use: To upgrade plantation

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita Q. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old. Nenita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Nenita buys and sells coconuts for copra (dried coconut meat used for oil production) in the local community. Nenita has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Nenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional coconuts to sell. This will be the ninth loan taken by Nenita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional coconuts to sell

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie C. is from the village of Manaoag, Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 32 years old. Jessie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Jessie plants and harvests corn to sell. Jessie has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 30000 PHP every harvesting season (every four months).

In 2009, Jessie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessie has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Jessie is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be Jessie's third loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard is an ambitious married man with seven children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda with dreams of educating his children. For fourteen years he has been trading in cattle and his business dream is to venture into timber. Richard needs a loan to purchase timber for resale.

loans.use: Purchase of timber for resale.

loans.name: Souzane

texts.fr: Elle a 45 ans et est mariée. Elle a en charge 2 enfants. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus, la vente des mèches et compte dans cette activité 3 ans. Elle s’approvisionne au grand  marché  de Lomé et revend ensuite au marché de gbégnédi.  Pour avoir de nouveaux lots de mèches et satisfaire plus de clients, elle sollicite au près de WAGES un prêt.
texts.en: This 45-year-old woman is married with two children in her care. She makes a living selling hair extensions, and has three years of experience in this activity. She gets her merchandise at the big market of Lomé for sale at the Gbégnédi market. She is seeking a loan from WAGES to increase her stock of hair extensions and satisfy a larger customer base.

loans.use: Buying hair extensions

loans.name: Rwamarengye Mixed Farmers Group

texts.en: B. Deodanta is an individual client in Rukungiri. She is 44 years old and married with 3 children, all are in school.  She also takes care of other dependents. Deodanta has been an agriculturalist in Rwamarengye for 5 years, growing and selling matooke (bananas of the plantains type).  Being trustworthy has made her successful.  She is able to make 100,000 UGX in weekly profits.  She started this business after realizing that it was profitable. Previously she was involved in selling coffee.  Although she was able to get some profit from that business, it was too tiring for her as a woman.  This is one of the reasons why she changed businesses. She needs a loan to be able to buy more matooke for resale.

loans.use: To buy matooke (bananas) for resale.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en: G. Christopher is 68 and married with five children. He is a very committed man with an agricultural business where he sells and grows matooke from Kyatoko. He works hand in hand with his wife and children, in addition to selling vegetables in the same area. He has been in business for six years and he needs a loan to buy fertilizer and manure for improved output.

loans.use: To buying fertilizer and manure to improve matooke (plantain) production

loans.name: Kan

texts.en: Kan Y. is a 47-year-old mother caring for six children, five of whom are single, still living in the family home and employed in different jobs. Kan Y. is a recycling seller - she buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. She deals mostly in leftover electricity wires. Her husband is a domestic rice trader who owns a rice hulling machine. He provides a rice milling service to their neighbors for daily revenue. Kan Y. is looking for a loan to use as capital to buy more leftover electricity wire stock in order to increase her profits. Kan Y. and her husband are shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more stock in order to increase her profits.

loans.name: Komlanvi Jean

texts.fr: Jean a 2 enfants et est âgé de 30 ans. Il est tapissier de profession. Il achète à Ahépé, Kouvé et à Lomé les bois et revient fabriquer des meubles à des clients. Il cumule 6 ans dans cette activité. Il demande un prêt pour acheter 30 bois, 5 mousses, 2 boites de peinture et  5 sachets de clous.
texts.en: Jean has two children and is 30 years old. He is an upholsterer by trade. He buys his  supplies in  Ahépé, Kouvé and, as to the wooden parts, à Lomé and returns home to make furniture for his clients. He has six   years of experience in this business. He is seeking a loan in order to purchase 30 sets of wood, five packs of foam, two boxes of paint and five bags of nails.

loans.use: Purchasing wood, foam, paint and nails

loans.name: George

texts.en: George O. O. is a married man. His wife is a greengrocer and they have one child, aged three years old, whom they hope to educate to the university level. His business is located at Kisumu Central Business District. Kisumu is the region in Kenya which harbours Lake Victoria and is well known as the lake basin. He provides public transport around the busy Kisumu city. He has been in this business for five years now and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is the high cost of repairing the rickshaw. There is also increased thuggery in the area posing risk to his business and life. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy spare parts to repair the rickshaw, so it will stay in good condition to provide better service to his clients. He hopes to acquire another rickshaw in the future to increase his income. He describes himself as tolerant, assertive and persuasive.

loans.use: Spare parts

loans.name: Gertrude Mathilde

texts.fr:
Commerçante de 40 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont l'age varie entre 5 a 20 ans. A l'arrêt de ses études secondaires, n'ayant pas trouve un poste de travail, elle ouvre une boutique d'alimentation , ou l'on trouve les produits,des conserves, du lait en poudre et concentre, des sardines,du yaourt...
Elle a des ventes régulières de 25000f a 80000frs par jour, elle a rembourse son prêt sans trop de difficulté et a fait des epargnes considerables.
Au deuxieme pret , elle tient a renforcer son commerce et elargir le stand de son alimentation.
Tres pragmatique, elle veut etre une femme d'affaire et ouvrir une autre boutique dans peu de temps.
texts.en: A 40-year old merchant, married and the mother of four, between 5 and 20 years of age.  Not having been able to find a job  after finishing secondary school, she opened a grocery store, in which she sells canned food, milk powder and condensed milk, sardines, yoghurt, etc. Her usual sales range from 25,000 and 80,000 West African Francs per day. She repaid her [previous] loan without issues and was able to do save a good sum of money. With this second loan, she would like to strengthen her business and expand her stock. Very pragmatic, she would like to be a true businesswoman and open a second store shortly afterwards.

loans.use: Purchasing canned products, corned beef, sardines, milk powder, condened milk, etc,

loans.name: Patrick Arnaud Gildas

texts.fr:
jeune universitaire de 36 ans, célibataire avec 2 enfants a charge dont l'age se situe entre  2 et 12 ans,a la fin des études universitaires d'économie, il se lance en 2002 dans la vente des poissons de mer fumes comme harengs, maquerelles.
A l'octroi de son premier prêt, il acheté 10 des cartons harengs et 5 cartons de maquereaux, et par semaine, il a eu a faire deux livraisons, voir même trois , ses ventes ont augmentes, de 80.000frs par jour il pouvait vendre 150.000frs a 300.000frs, il a fait la vente en gros , demi gros et détail.Il a des fortes épargnes et a eu a rembourser sans difficultés.
A l'octroi de son second, il veut renforcer son stock en procédant dans le même sens, il pense maintenant faire des grosses commandes chez les pêcheurs Beninois  de Pointe noire.
Toujours très dynamique,il tient a aller au bout jusqu'à devenir un grand grossiste de poissons fumes, faire des grands bénéfices et s'occuper des études de ses enfants et acheter une parcelle pour sa famille .
texts.en:
A 36-year old college graduate, single with two children in his care, 2 and 12 years old. After obtaining his economics degree in 2002, he launched a business selling smoked sea fish such as herrings and mackerel. 

Thanks to his first loan, he bought ten boxes of herring and five boxes of mackerel. He had two to three deliveries made each week. His sales have grown from 80,000 West African francs to between 150,000 and 300,000 franks. He sells wholesale, semi-wholesale and retail. He has saved a lot and was able to repay his loan without issues. 

Thanks to his second loan, he would like to replenish his stock proceeding in a similar way. He is now thinking of placing large orders with Benin fishermen in Pointe Noire. Always very energetic, he is set on doing all he possibly can in order to become a major wholesaler trading in smoked fish, achieve a good income and be able to provide for his children’s studies as well as to purchase a land plot for his family.

loans.use: Purchasing smoked fish: herrings, mackerel

loans.name: Kikarara Minyeto Twimukye Bee Keepers Group

texts.en: T. Charles is 40 and married with eight children. Six of them are still in school and the rest are already working. He is a farmer in Nyakatemba A call in Rukungiri, and he is the leader of Kikara Minyeto group. He has been in the farming business for more than 10 years, growing food crops for sale. Working closely with his wife, he is able to make an average of 40,000 UGX profit a week. Charles also has a retail shop that helps to bring in more income. He is a good man and very hard working, and he needs a loan to be able to improve on his farming activities buying manure for his plantations. He hopes to be able to build a good house for his family.

loans.use: To buy manure to improve plantation productivity

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of beef

loans.name: Dalia Rubio Group

texts.en:
Dalia R. is from the village of Tonggo, Tudela Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old. Dalia is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Dalia R. Group.

Dalia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Dalia plants and harvests fruits and vegetables to sell. Dalia has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 6400 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Dalia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dalia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Dalia is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be Dalia's eighth loan  from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her farming business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To develop his project by making new decorations

loans.name: Fred Kyoma

texts.en: B. Fred Kyoma is from Rukungiri. He is 59 and married with eight children and is involved in growing and selling matooke with his wife. He operates from Kanyamuhe village. Through hard work, he is able to make 150,000 UGX in monthly profits. He is also involved in the sale of coffee to the coffee factory in his area and this supplements his income. He needs a loan to improve his plantation by applying manure.

loans.use: To buy manure to boost plantation production

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr: Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle est âgée de 40 ans. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus, la vente de charbons. Elle a démarré ses activités en 1998 et s’approvisionne au Nord du pays. Elle demande un prêt pour acheter 120 nouveaux sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en: She is married and mother of 2 children. She is 40 years old. She is in the revenue-generating business of selling charcoal.  She launched her business in 1998 and stocks up in the north of the country.  She is asking for a loan to buy 120 new bags of charcoal.

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal

loans.name: Lilian's Group

texts.en:
Lilian B. is from the village of Lemu Sur. She is 27 years old. Lilian is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lilian B..

Lilian is single. To make a living, Lilian owns & operates a business catching and selling fresh-water fish at the market. Lilian has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lilian joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilian is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lilian from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles O. O. is 30 years old, married, and has one child whom they hope to give good education to the university level. His wife is a business woman.  His business is located on Kisumu's Oginga Odinga Street. Kisumu is the region in Kenya where Lake Victoria is located. Charles sells microphones, speakers, VCDs,  and DVDs to the local people. He has been in this business for eight years. His business is profitable and the major challenge he faces is that he does not have a permanent place to run his business. At times, Charles also gets harassed by the local government. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. Charles is using his  80,000 KES loan to buy more electronics to increase his business, especially during this festive season. He hopes to acquire a permanent retail shop within the town. He sees himself being the major supplier of electronics in the city in the future. He describes himself as honest and trustworthy.

loans.use: To purchase electronics

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Il est  marié et  âgé de 36 ans.  IL a en charge 2 enfants.  Pour pouvoir s’occuper de ses enfants, il fait la vente de matériel électronique. Il a démarré en 2009 ses activités et achète ses matériels au grand marché de Lomé.  Il revend  ensuite vendre ses matériels dans une boutique sise à Bèkpota à côté de l’hôtel Bijou.  Avec le nouveau, il espère acheter  12 cartons d’ampoule, 2 cartons de câbles VGV et 5 compteurs.
texts.en: This 36-year-old married man has two children in his care. In  order to provide for his children, he sells electronic equipment. He started this activity in 2009, and gets his supplies at the main market in Lomé. The merchandise is then sold in a store located next to the Bijou hotel, in Bèkpota. With the new loan, he plans to buy 12 boxes of bulbs, 2 boxes of VGV cables and 5 meters.

loans.use: Purchase of electrical equipment

loans.name: Oung

texts.en: Oung K., age 30, lives in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. She is a housewife and she always stays at home to do some housework and manage other property in and around her house. She always cooks a nice meal for all members in the family, does some daily duties such as cleaning the house, washing clothes, and caring for her three children. Oung K.’s husband is skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He has a few physical laborers to help provide his service. He receives a lot of orders from his customers to construct their houses. Presently, he lacks funds to purchase additional equipment for construction to provide his building service. Therefore, Oung K. will use her loan to assist her husband's business.

loans.use: To purchase additional construction equipment

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida K. was born in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She graduated from trading college and has worked in this sphere for 30 years.  
In 2000, after the death of her husband, she became the only bread-winner for her three children. In order to find means of subsistence, Farida tried her hand at reselling footwear at the local market. In 2005, she obtained her first loan to broaden the range of goods she sold. This loan was used as intended and repaid without any delays.  

But in June 2010, Farida lost her business during violent clashes in the city of Osh caused by political turmoil. Her small shop was burned to ashes. However, she doesn’t give up easily and is ready to resume her lost business and continue her work. To help her do this, Farida is applying for a loan of 135,000 KGS. She plans to spend the extra profits on providing a good education for her daughter.  

Farida is optimistic person, who doesn't look back and moves ahead. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners use Kiva funding to assist the especially vulnerable. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to broaden an assortment of goods

loans.name: Luzviminda's Group

texts.en:
Luzviminda D. is from the village of Casalatan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 51 years old. Luzviminda is the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Luzviminda is married and has 9 adult children. She owns & operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes  from selling vegetables in the local community. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2007, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Luzviminda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. 

Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be again be used for inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Luzviminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Kodzo Adodo

texts.fr: Adodo est âgé de  65 ans et  a 4 enfants en charge. IL fait la vente des articles scolaires pour s’occuper de sa petite famille. IL a débuté ses activités en 1978 et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. IL revend ensuite ses articles dans la Librairie la Lumière en face de l’hotel John Palace dans le quartier Akodessewa sur la route de Zorro bar.  Il demande un prêt pour acquerir de nouveaux articles scolaires et satisfaire plus de clients.
texts.en: Adodo is 65 years old and has 4 children to support. He sells school supplies to take care of his small family.  He started his business in 1978 and stocks up at the main market in Lomé.  He then resells the items at the Librairie la Lumiere (Light Bookstore) in front of the John Palace hotel in the Akodessewa neighborhood on the Zorro Bar road. He is asking for a loan to acquire new school supplies and satisfy more clients.

loans.use: Purchase of School Supplies

loans.name: Seav

texts.en:
Seav S., age 26, is married with one child who is attending school. Currently, Seav S. lives in the province of Kompong Tom. She is a domestic rice trader, and she also buys rice in bulk at a reasonable cost, and then resells the rice to people to earn a living. Her husband works with her in the business. 

In addition, Seav S. is also feeding some pigs behind her house. Usually Seav S. generates around $4 of income a day to meet the needs of her family. This rice harvesting season, Seav S. needs capital to purchase many sacks of rice to store. She will sell them when the rice commands the highest price. She hopes that she will use any remainder to buy more piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase many sacks of rice to store and if possible buy more small pigs to raise

loans.name: Cerlas' Group

texts.en:
Cerlas D. is from the village of Nangalisan. She is 52 years old. Cerlas is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Cerlas D.'.

Cerlas is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Cerlas owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Cerlas has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cerlas joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cerlas is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Cerlas from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith A. O. is a married lady. She and her husband have one child three years old whom they hope to give a good education up to the university level. Her business is located at Kisumu's Kibuye market and it is well known as Jaringa workshop. Kisumu is the region in Kenya which habours Lake Victoria and is well know as the lake basin. 

Judith sells door frames, window frames, beds and wheelbarrows to the local people and other retailers who buy to resell. She has been in this business for one year now and has four employees. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is power-rationing slowing down her business. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more zed metal to use to make window frames, and scrap metal and square bars to make the items that she sells. She hopes to grow her business and open other outlets to make more income. She describes herself as strict, humble and truthful.

loans.use: Scrap metal, zed metal, square bars, etc

loans.name: Ntungamo Bakyara Tuhirirwe Group

texts.en:
B. Salvano is the leader of Ntungamo Bakyara Tuhirirwe in Ntungamo. He is 44 years old and married with five children.

Salvano is involved in the sale of vegetables, including dodo, tomatoes, eggplants and so on. He has been in this business for eight years. From this work, he is able to make a weekly profit of 80,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX). (About $35 U.S. dollars a week.)

In addition, Salvano has a hotel business that contributes to his income. He was introduced to the business by a friend of his. Before this, he was only selling water for a living. 

Salvano is social and hardworking and he hopes to continue his children's education so that they may have a much brighter future. He needs a loan to be able to buy fertilizers and pesticides for his vegetable gardens.

loans.use: Buying fertilizers and pesticides for his vegetable gardens.

loans.name: Sweetie Pie

texts.en:
Sweetie Pie L. is from the village of Magsaysay. She is 42 years old. Sweetie Pie is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Sweetie Pie owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sweetie Pie has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Sweetie Pie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sweetie Pie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Sweetie Pie is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Sweetie Pie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan K., 58, is a village woman living in Kompong Cham Province. She is a local crop farmer, growing rice, vegetables, and corn on her own farmland. Her husband is a local farmer, and he helps her in the farming business as well. This couple has eight children, four of whom are single. The other four are married. They have two children who work in a casino in Kompong Sam Province, and they have a salary about $80 per month. 

The coming rainfall will be good for her crop, however, Chan K. doesn’t have capital yet to use on her farm. So, Chan K. is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizers, corn seed, and vegetables for planting.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, corn seeds, and vegetables to plant

loans.name: Rwentobo Tukore Women's Group

texts.en: Rwentobo is the group that B. Constance belongs to. She is 35 years old and married with one child. She has a salon business selling cosmetics, hair treatments, plaiting and so on. Constance is able to make 70,000/= as profit per week. Her salon is situated in Rwentobo Trading Centre and she serves the local people in her area. She has been operating her salon for over 10 years using personal savings from the retail shop that she owned before. She needs a loan to buy more cosmetics and stock more weaves for sale.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and stock more weaves for sale

loans.name: Deo

texts.en:
B. Deo is a secondary school teacher offering educational services to students and the community. His school is Bwogyera Secondary School. He also has a retail shop and farms, and he is able to make 392,036/= in monthly profit. He has been in business for 28 years as a teacher after going through training. 

B. Deo is an individual client from Ntungamo. He is 58 years old and married with four children. He is very hardworking and dependable. He needs a loan to restock his retail shop for the season so that he can pay school fees for his children come February next year.

loans.use: To restock his retail shop with more goods

loans.name: Srosh

texts.en:
The woman in this photograph is Srosh S..  She is 29 years old and lives in Kompong Cham Province, a good location for farming. Srosh S. is a married woman who is devoted to her two young children.  Her children attend school and depend on her for care. 

Srosh S. has a  farm which she inherited from her grandparents. Her husband also helps her to grow crops. They are currently planting peanut and rice crops.  They estimate that the harvest will be within the next month, when the plants mature. Srosh S. also owns another farm, but she is not planting crops on it. Srosh S. hopes to use this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers for growing crops.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Kayi Youyou

texts.fr: Youyou a 2 enfants  en charge et est âgée de 33 ans. Elle  est mariée à un transitaire. Pour participer au ménage, elle fait la vente de produits génériques. Elle achète ses produits au Ghana à Accra et au Togo-pharma. Dans cette activité, elle compte 4 ans et redistribue ensuite dans une pharmacie à Adakpamé. Elle sollicite un prêt pour renouveler les stocks.
texts.en:
Youyou is 33 years old and has two children. She is married to a shipping agent. To play her part in the household, she sells generic pharmaceutical products. 

Youyou buys her products in Accra, Ghana and at Togo-pharma. She then sells them to a pharmacy in Adakpamé. She has been involved in this business activity for four years. 

She is requesting a loan to replenish her stocks.

loans.use: To buy generic pharmaceutical products

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is married with two grown children. She lives in Ivano-Frankivsk. Galina sells men’s outerwear, underwear, socks and hats in the central market in her home town. Her prices are very affordable for middle class customers. She has been in this trade for 4 years. Presently, her income amounts to 6,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Galina is seeking a loan of 7,500 Grivnyas to buy assorted men’s sportswear, underwear, socks and winter hats. She is planning to invest the loan in the purchase of 20 pairs of sweats, 10 sports jackets and a variety of underwear and socks. One of Galina’s business plans is to expand her business and open a second vending location in the market.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Kamuli Road Twekalangule - Jinja Group

texts.en:
50-year-old K. Annet says she set forth in her current grocery store enterprise after the demise of her husband. She was at her wits end, and coming to grips with her predicament was the turning point. With 12 kids to provide welfare for, Annet knew she had to do something to bring substantial value to their lives. What exacerbated her situation from the start is the fact that she did not have any prior business experience. But, with conviction, she conquered the odds stacked against her. 

The grocery business has now lasted five years. It is located along Kamuli Road which is near the Jinja metropolis. She has mostly been selling fruits and vegetables. She says her weekly profits are to the tune of 180,000 shillings. With this loan, Annet, a member of the Kamuli Road Twekalangule Group, says she is going to buy more vegetables and fruits to sell. She envisages better prospects for her business in the future. Now that the Christmas festive season is in the offing, she says she is looking forward to a roaring trade selling fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a larger variety and amount of goods to sell in the store

loans.name: Oksana

texts.en:
Oksana is a single mom raising a 5-year-old son. Oksana is a small entrepreneur from Ivano-Frankivsk. She sells sportswear, e.g. t-shirts, sweatsuits and athletic footwear in the central marketplace of her home town. She launched her enterprise 17 years ago. Currently, her monthly income amounts to 7,000 Grivnyas.  

Oksana is requesting a loan of 8,000 Grivnyas to purchase an assortment of winter sportswear to meet her clients’ demands. She is hoping to buy 50 pairs of sweats and 20 sports jackets,  thus diversifying her merchandise. Oksana admits she was forced to try her luck in business and launched her startup when she failed to find a job as a vet. One of her long-term plans is to open her own sportswear and footwear store some day. This business is her only source of income.

loans.use: To purchase winter sportswear for resale

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a married woman with three children, all of whom are attending school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has been operating a firewood selling business for the past six years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Mercy faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase firewood for resale

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en:
Chuon K. is 55 years old.  She owns a small shop by the street where she sells soft drinks, food and other goods. She typically makes around US$ 3 in profit each day to support her family. She had been married but she divorced her husband years ago. She has five children, all are married and most are employed in different jobs. They often help Chuon K. by sharing their earnings to help her with daily expenses. 

At the present, Chuon K. is concerned that her kitchen is too small and old. She wants to rebuild it but lacks the money to do so. To address this situation, Chuon K. is seeking a loan from Kiva to rebuild her kitchen.

loans.use: To rebuild the kitchen

loans.name: Salissou

texts.fr: Salissou a 24 ans. IL est né  à  Lomé  et vit dans le quartier  Lycée de Tokoin. IL gère comme activité génératrice de revenus, la vente de la viande de chèvre et compte dans cette activité  10 ans déjà. Il vend ensuite ses viandes à abattoir de port de pèche. Avec le nouveau crédit, il espère acheter 20 chèvres.
texts.en: Salissou is 24 years old.  He was born in Lomé and lives in the Lycée district of Tokoin.  He has been managing his business of selling goat meat for 10 years.  He sells his meat at the abattoir at the fishing port.  With this new loan, he hopes to buy 20 goats.

loans.use: to buy goats

loans.name: Nakale

texts.en:
Nakale is a married woman with eight children, all of whom attend school.  She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a charcoal sales business, selling from her home to her neighbours and passersby.  Nakale faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business.  She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With 25,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Dedan

texts.en:
Dedan O. N. is thirty eight years old.  His wife is a hotelier and they have four children who are between the ages of two and nine years old.  They hope to give them all a good education up to the university level.  His business is located on the shores of Lake Victoria.  Kisumu is the region in Kenya in which Lake Victoria is located and it is well known as the lake basin. 

He sells fish which he gets from Lake Victoria.  He has been in this business for fifteen years now.  He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is climatic changes and strong waves on the lake.  However he works to keep his business doing well.  He is using his loan of 80,000 KES to buy a motor boat to expand his business and meet the demands of his customers, especially during the festive season.  He hopes to acquire many more motor boats to expand his business and make more income in the future.  He describes himself as innovative and flexible.

loans.use: To buy a motor boat to expand his business.

loans.name: Chidi Francis

texts.fr: Francis est âgé de 40 ans.  Il exerce la vente des pièces détachées. IL a demarré ses  activités en 1998 et s’approvisionne au port autonome de Lomé.  Ensuite, il redistribue les pièces dans un atelier à Attiégou à côté de L’hôtel la référence. IL demande un prêt pour acheter de nouvelles pièces détachées.
texts.en: Francis is 40 years old. He sells spare parts.  He got involved in this work in 1998 and he gets his supplies at the autonomous port of Lomé.  He then resells them in his shop in Attiégou next to L’Hôtel la Référence.  He is requesting a loan to buy more spare parts.

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Fenny

texts.en:
Fenny is a single woman with two children who have graduated from school.  She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling from her home to her neighbours.  Fenny faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  She hopes to expand and operate a wholesale shop in the future.

With 25,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase kitchen utensils (jugs, cups, plates) for resale.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans and improve her living standards.
